1E3DA98CA63A4561A762811CC9518805.description: Discuss how the uses of science can have a global environmental impact.

45DAA5C9B0C64AA1BE3946582E9CB5A1.description: Describe how people develop and use scientific understanding as individuals and through collaboration, e.g. through peer-review.

1A5EFE9FD79946AC8CDAC513FFD235A6.description: Evaluate issues which involve and/or require scientific understanding.

FFF584CD6CA04B96A964B7B4AC8804E0.description: Describe how science is applied across societies and industries, and in research.

8B933A49EFFB464090E466D3ABCF1E75.description: Discuss how scientific knowledge is developed through collective understanding and scrutiny over time.

77C995B99D024446B474698B99C967C1.description: Know that nebulae are clouds of dust and gas, and can act as stellar nurseries.

37B79FDA20004464A4ACD7287D615DED.description: Describe the evidence for the collision theory for the formation of the Moon.

8B3FC8222C8C4883B068AA636E35BA05.description: Describe the consequences of asteroid collision with the Earth, including climate change and mass extinctions.

ED7319C591ED49FB98C0C6EE6F5E08A3.description: Describe the historical and predicted future impacts of climate change, including sea level change, flooding, drought and extreme weather events.

FBA4CC1D55994BF0A86BC825C6B7F830.description: Describe the carbon cycle (limited to photosynthesis, respiration, feeding, decomposition and combustion).

B8C194A570F14F33873513FAAF9FF487.description: Explain why the jigsaw appearance of continental coasts, location of volcanoes and earthquakes, fossil record and alignment of magnetic materials in the Earth's crust are all evidence for tectonic plates.

305EA885EBF849139B93DE0E29AD2819.description: Explain the movement of tectonic plates in terms of convection currents.

F916379E59214FEC83A9B9694D270D2A.description: Use diagrams and conventional symbols to represent, make and compare circuits that include cells, switches, resistors (fixed and variable), ammeters, voltmeters, lamps and buzzers.

05E6AA57A72E44D095900A24F716DBD9.description: Calculate resistance (resistance = voltage / current) and describe how resistance affects current.

1065D6242B724E4B99570D5BBF86E3EA.description: Know how to measure current and voltage in series and parallel circuits, and describe the effect of adding cells and lamps.

3A44FFDDF8A2467583D1C0E072FFD4B8.description: Describe how current divides in parallel circuits.

DED28C2586AE4C46A3A96FA98B427A42.description: Use waveforms to show how sound waves interact to reinforce or cancel each other.

C58CA4F427EA453295BDD2546627CE5F.description: Draw and interpret waveforms, and recognise the link between loudness and amplitude, pitch and frequency.

8EFB0EBC41034DF2AFA63E4DBC415952.description: Describe thermal transfer by the processes of conduction, convection and radiation.

6BFA2D079D874B24AC8C0B0A7289FF5B.description: Know that thermal energy will always transfer from hotter regions or objects to colder ones, and this is known as heat dissipation.

9898394FD8814F7BAED88270E893AE87.description: Know that energy is conserved, meaning it cannot be created or destroyed.

445E660DEEAC4A07AFE7C9CB8AABB8F8.description: Describe the difference between heat and temperature.

B47DDF9BFD214147991BC6E613EDD682.description: Use density to explain why objects float or sink in water.

A48F6FD64DD643AD96751A6FD8E05EA5.description: Understand that in chemical reactions mass and energy are conserved.

F9DD0D239A0F47529F5E76AB03B251EC.description: Describe the effects of concentration, surface area and temperature on the rate of reaction, and explain them using the particle model.

05E40593598346F0BA1F708C9D5CCA32.description: Describe how to prepare some common salts by the reactions of metals with acids, and metal carbonates with acids, and purify them, using filtration, evaporation and crystallisation.

E3AA4DC7ACAD4E458A545A397207B522.description: Identify examples of displacement reactions and predict products (limited to reactions involving calcium, magnesium, zinc, iron, copper, gold and silver salts).

85E2172C49C443CFBB5BC17F0CCBD967.description: Use word equations and symbol equations to describe reactions (balancing symbol equations is not required).

DFBC8242C2124A28A73ECE02CAD89F7B.description: Know that elements and compounds exist in structures (simple or giant), and this influences their physical properties.

CB95935AFDCE40609C6BADD9E1A506BB.description: Calculate and compare densities of solids, liquids and gases.

F3A06F7DAC5A4660B4D0FAE616BC0715.description: Describe how the density of a substance relates to its mass in a defined volume.

5C14655A02254E8190BA52BF722C7396.description: Understand that the groups within the Periodic Table have trends in physical and chemical properties, using group 1 as an example.

BD634247241844339EE955B4B66CAA9D.description: Describe an ionic bond as an attraction between a positively charged ion and a negatively charged ion.

3932C7053DA149778BC0785647D9F259.description: Describe an ion as an atom which has gained at least one electron to be negatively charged or lost at least one electron to be positively charged.

E97BCB18AB0840FABD136F7338E63C05.description: Describe a covalent bond as a bond made when a pair of electrons is shared by two atoms (limited to single bonds).

D8720603F5A44C9180E534E15CA3A74D.description: Understand that a molecule is formed when two or more atoms join together chemically, through a covalent bond.

476B8B226FE54ECFA06E3E8B262E0070.description: Understand that the structure of the Periodic Table is related to the atomic structure of the elements and the Periodic Table can be used to predict an elementâ€™s structure and properties.

E2E3BC0846954E9B812671F2C4CCE5E7.description: Describe what could happen to the population of a species, including extinction, when there is an environmental change.

35E2526FAD6B417FAB1F634216C6DFC7.description: Discuss how fetal development is affected by the health of the mother, including the effect of diet, smoking and drugs.

73B8675DC8764854913F77DCED34EA09.description: Know and use the summary word equation for photosynthesis (carbon dioxide + water -> glucose + oxygen, in the presence of light and chlorophyll).

840A65767D0649EAAA07539B5E93FF6D.description: Know that photosynthesis occurs in chloroplasts and is the process by which plants make carbohydrates, using the energy from light.

F4281D4E478A44E3AB4AA6D59D80298F.description: Know that plants require minerals to maintain healthy growth and life processes (limited to magnesium to make chlorophyll and nitrates to make protein).

69DA6286AFF342FE9131CA11B90B406B.description: Describe the scientific theory of natural selection and how it relates to genetic changes over time.

3FCB50457C384235BBD3B4C2B15A1A7D.description: Describe variation within a species and relate this to genetic differences between individuals.

15CC41F8A8FB4778B1B849E87F025932.description: Describe the inheritance of sex in humans in terms of XX and XY chromosomes.

7517882F88784B53BB3DFDBF54CE064B.description: Describe the fusion of gametes to produce a fertilised egg with a new combination of DNA.

EE37111D423743549328D71E34E1056E.description: Know that chromosomes contain genes, made of DNA, and that genes contribute to the determination of an organism's characteristics.

E6F9FAA807824D4582DBD33EE819A765.description: Describe the structure of the human excretory (renal) system and its function (limited to kidneys filtering blood to remove urea, which is excreted in urine).

9AE958BC89474EA9ADE852996DA8E6AE.description: Describe the pathway of water and mineral salts from the roots to the leaves in flowering plants, including absorption in root hair cells, transport through xylem and transpiration from the surface of leaves.

3409E456BE774BFA8ED67E4DFC146E8D.description: Present and interpret results, and predict results between the data points collected.

A4A98C5350DC450293D141D7FE9861AD.description: Evaluate experiments and investigations, including those by others, and suggest improvements, explaining any proposed changes.

778CFAE3BDEE4F8EB6D1835A0B733824.description: Make conclusions by interpreting results, explain the limitations of the conclusions and describe how the conclusions can be further investigated.

E9355067862A454A8BBD90A5C18A2556.description: Describe trends and patterns in results, identifying any anomalous results and suggesting why results are anomalous.

E1CF633AC8E340EFAED2D04E49101E9A.description: Evaluate the strength of the evidence collected and how it supports, or refutes, the prediction.

1394BB1E629243258F99C3F8B72BFE7A.description: Scientific enquiry: analysis, evaluation and conclusions

58FB1AAD16C147B0B50A620F2ACE13C1.description: Collect, record and summarise sufficient observations and measurements, in an appropriate form.

ECD6FD650D2A49BAAFE488652839449B.description: Make an informed decision whether to use evidence from first-hand experience or secondary sources.

F15A8906D93B4C3C92728E55DEA89634.description: Carry out practical work safely, supported by risk assessments where appropriate.

BBF0BF352D4C4C4D8156E98351800BE3.description: Take appropriately accurate and precise measurements, explaining why accuracy and precision are important.

2A5772145CD549E9A33EC50339C32E20.description: Decide when to increase the range of observations and measurements, and increase the extent of repetition, to give sufficiently reliable data.

06F0BB89CA8344679731A32FA775D489.description: Decide what equipment is required to carry out an investigation or experiment and use it appropriately.

8D0216BDE5314186A395FDCE94AED79F.description: Sort, group and classify phenomena, objects, materials and organisms through testing, observation, using secondary information, and making and using keys.

BBE881386C374F84A0BF8C0661BD45ED.description: Make risk assessments for practical work to identify and control risks.

DAE2D5F01D764D20B117F5DF98A415EB.description: Plan a range of investigations of different types to obtain appropriate evidence when testing hypotheses.

DDA17172C0504E6AA8F4D0DCDFFE274F.description: Make predictions of likely outcomes for a scientific enquiry based on scientific knowledge and understanding.

9250A4C229374D3AB4839F289871691B.description: Describe examples where scientists' unexpected results from enquiries have led to improved scientific understanding.

2079B54334794E1E9F59790C191A591E.description: Suggest a testable hypothesis based on scientific understanding.

EA9CC8CD02EC43D9AD657CC57774DDE0.description: Use symbols and formulae to represent scientific ideas.

40DA7C70073B4072ABE074649C8F56D8.description: Describe some important models, including analogies, and discuss their strengths and limitations.

F51F4580F27A4BAF8B1CEA51EF9CF6FD.description: Understand that models and analogies reflect current scientific evidence and understanding and can change.
